Article.Abstract: It has been suggested that mutations within immunodominant cytotoxic T-lymphocyte (CTL) epitopes may be exploited by viruses to evade protective immune responses critical for clearance. Viral escape could originate from passive mechanisms, such as mutations within crucial CTL epitopes, either affecting major histocompatibility complex binding or T-cell antigen receptor (TCR) recognition. Additionally, it has recently been shown that substitutions of TCR contact sites can yield analogue peptides that can still interact with the T-cell receptor but be unable to deliver a full stimulatory signal, thus inducing anergy or acting as an antagonist for the TCR. We report here that hepatitis B virus isolates derived from two chronically infected patients display variant epitopes that act as natural TCR antagonists with the capacity to inhibit the CTL response to the wild-type epitope. During natural infection, TCR antagonist mutations of CTL epitopes could contribute to the development of viral persistence, especially if the antiviral CTL response is monospecific or the epitope is strongly immunodominant.
Article.ArticleTitle: Natural variants of cytotoxic epitopes are T-cell receptor antagonists for antiviral cytotoxic T cells.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Imported from the TopBank database. This is a variable region, as determined from sequencing of viruses from clinical isolates.
Imported from the TopBank database. This is a variable region, as determined from sequencing of viruses from clinical isolates.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: CTL clones were produced by limiting dilution from HBV-specific CTL lines derived from 2 patients with acute self-limited HBV infection. CTLs were stimulated with HBc 18-27 (FLPSDFFPSV).

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTLs specific for the peptide FLPSDFFPSV (HBV core 17-27) lysed target cells pulsed with high concentrations of the epitope.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Imported from the TopBank database. This peptide is derived from a HBV clinical isolate, and is from a variable region. No match can be found in SP/Genbank sources.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: A CTL clone (G5) specific for the epitope secreted IFNŒ≥ when stimulated with the epitope. IFNŒ≥ secretion is antagonized upon incubation with peptide variants ( at positions 21 and 27) of the epitope.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTLs specific for the epitope lysed target cells transfected with a plasmid carrying the whole HBV core gene (ayw subtype). Lysis is antagonized upon incubation with peptide variants of the epitope (at positions 21 and 27).
